data.title: Separate DocumentSymbolProvider structure semantics from type semantics
data.body:
Currently the symbol kind mixes structure and type. Some things could be multiple things at the same time.

For example there's `variable`, `constant`, `field` and then there's `string`.  The latter could legitimately also represent a variable, a constant or a field. It's not clear which kind to return in which situation. It could be useful to have these become separate fields and separate enums.

At the same time some uses of the symbol API (I have an extension that provides a code outline) could use information about either the actual type or at least its string signature/representation (think `(x: string): string` or `(name, amount)`).

data.body: Autocompletion prints folder or file name twice when using emojis in $PS1. At the beginning of the line and where it is supposed to (the end). This is my .bash_profile settings: export PS1="😡 [\W]$ " 2. (from home folder) cd Desk and then press tab for autocomplete (Desktop) OR (from home folder) cd Desktop and then press the "/" separator. Home folder and Desktop are only two example folders.

data.title: Callstack not correct when exiting a function to top-most frame.
Integrated terminal redraws $PS1 repeatedly while typing
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.5, Ubuntu 14.04.5 LTS

Other env config:
- Shell: zsh
- Shell manager: oh-my-zsh + powerlevel9k

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I have left and right side zsh utilities in place
2. An extra path is added after the $PS1 when not typing
2.a this is a copy of the displayed path
2.b only the last two dir paths are displayed, these are duplicated in the shell when not typing

example of desired:
```console
.../parent-dir/current-dir >
```

example after upgrade to 1.13 (shell operates correctly pre 1.13 and system terminals):
```console
.../parent-dir/current-dir/parent-dir/current-dir >
```

3. start typing and the $PS1 reverts to normal (only while typing characters)
3.a this causes a flipflop between `.../parent-dir/current-dir` and `.../parent-dir/current-dir/parent-dir/current-dir` while typing.

I haven't tracked down yet where the conflict is coming from, i.e. is it zsh, oh-my-zsh, or powerlevel9k. Something did change after the 1.13 release, as there were no issues before with the same configuration.

data.title: Go To Definition and Breakpoints
data.body:

I am currently working in a PHP environment on Windows 7.  

When I use any action to "Go To Definition" the editor now opens up a new tab even when the definition is within the same file. In this duplicated file that has navigated to the definition, I am not able to add a breakpoint for debugging. The only way to put a breakpoint in place is to go back to the original tab for the file, and use a different approach to navigation to the line I need to get to.

data.title: [Terminal - Windows] Ctrl+c doesn't work
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: Insiders bbcd10...
- OS Version: Windows 10 (Insiders)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a new integrated terminal
2. Type "node" to run nodejs
3. Type `ctrl + c` (several times)

What happens?
Nothing

What should happen?
The first time `ctrl + c` is pressed, nodejs should print out `(To exit, press ^C again or type .exit)` and the second time it is pressed, it should exit nodejs.

Note that it works fine with a standard (external) cmd prompt.

Here is my settings.json file:

```
// Place your settings in this file to overwrite the default settings
{
    "terminal.integrated.cursorBlinking": true,
    "terminal.integrated.lineHeight": 1.3,
    "workbench.editor.enablePreview": false,
    "workbench.editor.enablePreviewFromQuickOpen": false,
    "window.openFilesInNewWindow": false,
    "window.reopenFolders": "one",
    "typescript.check.tscVersion": false,
    "workbench.sideBar.location": "left",
    "window.zoomLevel": 0,
    "workbench.activityBar.visible": true,
    "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\WINDOWS\\Sysnative\\cmd.exe",
    "terminal.integrated.rightClickCopyPaste": true,
    "terminal.integrated.cursorStyle": "line",
    "terminal.integrated.fontLigatures": true,
    "terminal.integrated.fontFamily": "Consolas",
    "workbench.quickOpen.closeOnFocusLost": true,
    "workbench.iconTheme": "vscode-great-icons",
    "hexdump.width": 32,
    "window.menuBarVisibility": "toggle",
    "workbench.colorTheme": "Dracula",
    "editor.formatOnPaste": true
}
```

data.title: Streamline keybindings.json editor split view

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13
- OS Version: macOS Sierra

Editing user preferences is very nice in VS Code. It has a split panel view inside the editor tab with search and more fine grained tabs to select which settings are being edited (user vs. workspace settings). Here's how it looks like:

![screen shot 2017-06-13 at 16 56 35](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1101002/27088919-4de7f04c-5059-11e7-8afc-b4cf7e082768.png)

When editing keyboard shortcuts, the editor looks like this:

![screen shot 2017-06-13 at 16 56 42](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1101002/27088958-616f4494-5059-11e7-9e48-1ddc0841d958.png)

Also great, I have search and a nice table view with all the shortcuts in a readable format. However, almost always I opt to view `keybindings.json`, which looks like this:

![screen shot 2017-06-13 at 16 56 45](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1101002/27089361-6f20b6ee-505a-11e7-8b39-a527a2b1ec9d.png)

So, now the VS Code opened two new tabs in split view. Ok, this makes sense, I can see the defaults and the user settings, just like with `settings.json`.

**Except** that this opened the tabs in separate panels, and now my editor is split. If I want to go back to any of my other tabs to test out my new keyboard combination, I get this:

![screen shot 2017-06-13 at 16 56 48](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1101002/27089568-08b1d32e-505b-11e7-8b3e-4f9130f8545d.png)

Not ideal! It's ok to use a normal file with 50 % of the screen real estate, but the `settings.json` is further split in half by the editor. The result is a weird mix of these two split panel patterns. And even if I didn't happen to have `settings.json` open in the other panel, I still have to manually close both new tabs and the keybindings editor to get to where I was.

Sometimes the reason I use `keybindings.json` over the editor is that I can see all of my user shortcuts at once. But more often, I do it when I've set up a new shortcut for myself, tried it out and decided to try another combination. I think it's typical for users to test multiple shortcuts for any given command to see if they can learn it or if it matches their muscle memory when coming from another platform or editor. In this scenario the user goes through this flow repeatedly.

## Suggestions

A couple of possible solutions:

- Provide a menu item under _Preferences_ to open `keybindings.json` directly. Currently the easiest way for me to open that file is the full-featured keyboard shortcut editor, which has the link that triggers this issue.
- Prevent the issue from materializing by open only the user's `keybindings.json` with the link in the keybinding editor, or provide separate links
- Use similar tab layout next to the search field in the keybindings editor as is used in the settings to limit the list of keybindings to only defaults, user shortcuts etc. This is probably my preferred solution as it replicates the UX pattern used in settings, and is immediately accessible when opening keyboard shortcuts. You would still have to have the button for accessing the JSON but there would be less need to do so.

Overall I think this is a minor UX annoyance issue, but one that I encounter quite often. Making keyboard shortcuts accessible and lowering the threshold of customizing them to the absolute minimum can help a lot of users increase their productivity and enjoyment with the editor.

data.title: [decorators] renderIndentGuides don't move with a before decoration
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.14.0-insider (bbcd10ae1a959c1681469533321fa418da7cd9db, 2017-06-13T05:13:35.880Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.16215
---

This is probably a duplicate of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11485 but I wanted to make sure.

## Before
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/641685/27087719-c84a51da-5023-11e7-8214-197395b00732.png)

## After
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/641685/27087772-e8e5fea8-5023-11e7-8e74-ba53002aa4c7.png)

It's a bit hard to see, but you should be able to see that the indent lines are in the same position in both screenshots -- and I would expect them to move along with the code.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Make sure `editor.renderIndentGuides` is enabled
2. Toggle blame annotations with GitLens or add a `before` decoration to the lines

Related to https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-gitlens/issues/91

data.title: Content hover displays wrong html link
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.14.0-insider - OS Version: Windows 10 OS Build 15063.296 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a new file `test.js` with below content ``` $().bind(); ``` 2. Hover your mouse on `bind`, it shows ![test](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5811576/27085923-375af1c4-5083-11e7-9255-240e67669833.png) Notice that the link is ``` https://api.jquery.com/bind/#bind-eventType-eventData-handler} ``` There is an extra `}` at the end of the link. When you click on this link, the browser will also go to this incorrect link. 3. Open Developer Tools, you will find the the source code: ``` https://api.jquery.com/bind/#bind-eventType-eventData-handler} ``` BTW, The definition of function bind is: ``` /** * Attach a handler to an event for the elements. * * @param eventType A string containing one or more DOM event types, such as "click" or "submit," or custom event names. * @param eventData An object containing data that will be passed to the event handler. * @param handler A function to execute each time the event is triggered. * @see {@link https://api.jquery.com/bind/#bind-eventType-eventData-handler} */ bind(eventType: string, eventData: any, handler: (eventObject: JQueryEventObject) => any): JQuery; ``` My guess is that the bug might exist here, but I'm not sure. https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/base/browser/htmlContentRenderer.ts#L130-L141

Steps to Reproduce:

I am not running behind any proxy (as far as I know). I have the issue when I'm at home or work on the same laptop. I do however use Fiddler during development, so it's possible the proxy it sets up is not being removed, but I'm not sure how to determine if this is true or not.

In a last ditch attempt I tried uninstalling the plugin, then reinstalling, now I have no plugin and crippled vim-dependent typing skills.

This may be a vscodevim issue, if so let me know.

data.title: ${workspaceRoot} is empty when no file is open
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 64bit

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a folder with vscode
2. Create `.vscode/tasks.json`
3. Add a task:

```
{
    "taskName": "7. Check",
    "command": "start",
    "args": ["cmd /k \"${workspaceRoot}\\check.bat\""],
    "showOutput": "never",
    "isShellCommand": true
}
```

4. **Close all the files**
5. Run the task: **7. Check**

```
'\check.bat' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.
```

If you skip **4.** (or you have at least one open file) the file is executed properly.

#### The problem:

If there is no open file in the editor the `${workspaceRoot}` is equal to `""`

data.title: Insiders randomly crashing
